=== (*) Notes and recipes ===

==== Image seen on screen ====
* Manufacturer name: VIA/S3G UniChrome Pro IGP
* In Microsoft Windows is installed with "K817C0.inf"
* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 8.10 (Intrepid Ibex): Seems to autodetect the ''VIA - S3 Unichrome Pro'' device and apply some driver, but ''xserver'' hangs. Since this version Ubuntu project has removed packages <nowiki>[[http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?searchon=sourcenames&keywords=xserver-xorg-video-unichrome|xserver-xorg-video-unichrome]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?searchon=sourcenames&keywords=xserver-xorg-video-unichrome|xserver-xorg-video-via]]</nowiki> from the repositories. They have maintained only <nowiki>[[http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?searchon=sourcenames&keywords=xserver-xorg-video-openchrome|xserver-xorg-video-openchrome]]</nowiki>. We've run out graphic acceleration nor resolution.

The light way (without changing software):

# Boot on recovery mode. In Live-CD you can press [F6] at boot menu, delete the string '''splash --''', and add the word '''single'''
# When the system shows a text menu (''Recovery menu''), select "Drop to root shell prompt"
# Edit manually the file '''/etc/X11/xorg.conf''' (you can use the command ''nano /etc/X11/xorg.conf'')
# Insert a new line in the section "Device" with the following text: Driver "vesa"
# Introduce the command '''exit'''
# When the ''Recovery menu'' returns, select "Resume normal boot".

 You'll only view unaccelerated graphics at 800x600 resolution. That's all.

* Other references: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/OpenChrome
* Also read: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=264650
* Can try openchrome driver in u8.10?

==== Correct resolution ====

* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 6.06 (Dapper Drake): In Live-CD, even specifying 1280x800 in boot menu, screen goes to 1024x768.
* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 8.04 (Hardy Heron): Needed to edit manually the file '''/etc/X11/xorg.conf''' and add the folowing lines in the section "Screen":
<pre>
    DefaultDepth    24
    SubSection     "Display"
        Depth       24
        Modes      "1280x800" "1024x768" ""800x600"
    EndSubSection
</pre>
===== Ubuntu GNU/Linux 9.04 (Jaunty Jackalope) =====
* '''sudo dpkg-reconfigure -phigh xserver-xorg'''
* Insert the folowing lines in the section "Screen":
<pre>
	Subsection	"Display"
		Virtual	1280	800
	EndSubsection
</pre>

==== Graphic acceleration ====
* Manufacturer name: VIA/S3G UniChrome Pro IGP<BR>
* In Microsoft Windows is installed with "K817C0.inf"
* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 6.06 (Dapper Drake): Yes, but GL games often freeze.
* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 8.04 (Hardy Heron): Edit manually the file '''/etc/X11/xorg.conf''' and insert a new line in the section "Device" with the following text:
<pre>
        Driver          "via"
</pre>
* Other references: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/OpenChrome
* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 9.04 (Jaunty Jackalope): Seems to apply ''openchrome'' driver automatically.

==== Blank monitor on inactivity ====

* The screen shows strange image, like unsupported refresh rate.
* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 6.06 (Dapper Drake): Passed long time with screensavers the system completely freezes.
* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 9.04 (Jaunty Jackalope): Solved with openchrome driver.

==== Mic jack ====

* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 6.06 (Dapper Drake): Very low volume with Sound Recorder.

==== Wireless NIC ====

===== Ubuntu GNU/Linux 9.04 (Jaunty Jackalope) =====
# Install the '''ndiswrapper-utils-1.9''' package
# Download and unpack the <nowiki>[[http://support.acer-euro.com/drivers/notebook/as_1360.html|WinXP driver for Acer IPN2220 Wireless LAN Card NDIS Miniport Driver]]</nowiki>
# With a terminal go to the driver's directory (as 80211g/Winxp)
# '''sudo ndiswrapper -i neti2220.inf'''
# Check the neti2220 driver is installed and the device is found present with: '''sudo ndiswrapper -l'''
# If so: '''sudo modprobe ndiswrapper'''
# Check your network manager detects and connects wireless
# If so: '''sudo ndiswrapper -m''' to be loaded on boot.

===== Ubuntu GNU/Linux 8.04 (Hardy Heron) =====
Try the Jaunty method or:

https://help.ubuntu.com/community/WifiDocs/Device/ipn2220

===== Ubuntu GNU/Linux 7.10 (Gutsy Gibbon) =====
Try the Jaunty method

==== Live-CD boots until desktop ====

* Ubuntu GNU/Linux 5.04 (Hoary Hedgehog): Must select "vesa" for graphics. "via" fails.
